data.title: What to expect in the next 36 hours: Frigid temperatures, more lake-effect on the way
data.meta_description: A winter storm watch starts at 10 a.m. Tuesday, when 8 to 16 inches of lake effect snow are expected to land on Erie, Wyoming and Genesee counties through Thursday,
data.text:
Parts of the northtowns closest to Lake Erie, where a winter storm warning is in effect until 1 p.m., could see an additional 3 to 6 inches today that taper off this afternoon.

A narrow snow band hugging the shoreline may also drop slight accumulations of snow this morning from Buffalo to Blasdell.

But don't expect snow to hinder Josh Allen's passes at today's Bills game. Except for possible light flurries, little or no accumulation is expected in Orchard Park or anywhere else south of the city.

Think of it as a temporary snow reprieve.

Tuesday to Thursday

A winter storm watch starts at 10 a.m. Tuesday, when 8 to 16 inches of lake-effect snow are expected to land on Erie, Wyoming and Genesee counties through Thursday, according to the National Weather Service.

A widespread, light snow is expected to begin late Monday and deposit 1 to 2 inches over much of Western New York by morning.

Don't expect a break soon from the ice-cold temperatures that continue to grip Western New York, as well as much of the United States.

Listen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts

High temperatures are expected to be in the upper teens to low 20s across the region today through Wednesday, with the wind chill factor making it feel much colder, meteorologist Heather Kenyon said.

"It's going to remain cold with less wind than the last few days but the wind chill will still be in the single digits," Kenyon said.

The southtowns beginning Tuesday are expected to feel the brunt of the cold, with the wind chill making it feel even colder as snow blows and drifts.

The meteorologist had some advice today, while there is a temporary lull in snow for most of Western New York:

"During this break through tonight, it's a good time to make sure your outside pipes are clear and to shovel the paths around your house so it doesn't harden before the new snow drops," Kenyon said.

Breezy winds of 30 to 35 mph will accompany the lake-effect snow on Wednesday, according to the weather service. That means whiteout conditions will be possible within the snowbands.

Also, the lake-effect bands "will oscillate at least once from south to north and then back south again from Tuesday night through Thursday," according to the weather service.

Reach Aaron at abesecker[at]buffnews.com or 716-849-4602.
